message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Human-in-the-Loop Consensus Tracking Control for UAV Systems via an Improved Prescribed Performance Approach
Paper Abstract: In some crucial consensus tracking missions, the sign of the tracking error is not allowed to change during the tracking process. The existing tracking control schemes are unable to satisfy this requirement. To solve this issue, this work improves the conventional prescribed performance control (PPC) approach and applies it to the cooperative control of unmanned aircraft vehicle (UAV) systems. Moreover, the flight controller design incorporates human decision-making. This hybrid active interaction approach implies that humans and UAVs can execute complex and variable flight missions as a collaborative team. Considering that equipped motors are prone to faults when operating in harsh environments, this article presents an adaptive fuzzy fault compensation mechanism to ensure the flight safety of UAVs. Finally, the simulation study validates the effectiveness and control advantage of the proposed approach.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle UAV". Here are the key findings:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Key Characteristics

UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs), and are capable of controlled, sustained level flight and powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## History

UAVs were originally developed through the twentieth century for military missions.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

## Current Use and Adoption

By 2013 at least 50 countries used UAVs.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.

## Military Applications

An unmanned combat aerial vehicle (UCAV) is an unmanned aerial vehicle that carries aircraft ordnance such as air-to-surface missiles, anti-tank guided missiles (ATGMs), and/or aerial bombs, allowing it to perform tactical attacks known as drone strikes.

I've completed a web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle UAV". Here are the key findings:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Key Characteristics

UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs), and are capable of controlled, sustained level flight and powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## History

UAVs were originally developed through the twentieth century for military missions.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

## Current Use and Adoption

By 2013 at least 50 countries used UAVs.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.

## Military Applications

An unmanned combat aerial vehicle (UCAV) is an unmanned aerial vehicle that carries aircraft ordnance such as air-to-surface missiles, anti-tank guided missiles (ATGMs), and/or aerial bombs, allowing it to perform tactical attacks known as drone strikes.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about tracking control error:

## Tracking Error in Control Systems

In control systems, tracking error is defined as the difference between the desired output and the actual output: e(t) = r(t) − y(t), where r(t) is the desired output and y(t) is the measured output.

The aim of control systems is to develop a model or algorithm to drive the system to a desired state while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring control stability.

In feedback control systems, the difference between actual and desired output, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to the input of the system to bring the actual output closer to the reference.

## Application in PID Controllers

A PID controller continuously calculates an error value e(t) as the difference between a desired setpoint and a measured process variable and applies a correction based on proportional, integral, and derivative terms.

## Related Concept: Tracking Error in Finance

It's worth noting that in finance, tracking error or active risk is a measure of the risk in an investment portfolio that is due to active management decisions made by the portfolio manager; it indicates how closely a portfolio follows the index to which it is benchmarked. However, in the control systems context, tracking control error specifically refers to the deviation between desired and actual system output.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of control theory:

## Definition

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Links: [{"title":"Fuzzy control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_control_system"},{"title":"Fuzzy logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic"},{"title":"Fuzzy Control Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_Control_Language"},{"title":"Sendai Subway 1000 series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sendai_Subway_1000_series"},{"title":"Talk:Fuzzy control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Fuzzy_control_system"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"IEEE 1855 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_1855"},{"title":"Category:Fuzzy logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Fuzzy_logic"},{"title":"Fuzzy set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzification"},{"title":"Fuzzy Logic (Super Furry Animals album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_Logic_(Super_Furry_Animals_album)"}]

Here are the search results for "Fuzzy control logic":

## Overview

A fuzzy control system is a control system based on fuzzy logic – a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values of either 1.

## Key Concepts

The process of converting a crisp input value to a fuzzy value is called "fuzzification". Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.

## Historical Development

Fuzzy logic was proposed by Lotfi A. Zadeh of the University of California at Berkeley in a 1965 paper. The first industrial application, a cement kiln built in Denmark, came on line in 1976. 

Interest in fuzzy systems was sparked by Seiji Yasunobu and Soji Miyamoto of Hitachi, who in 1985 provided simulations that demonstrated the feasibility of fuzzy control systems for the Sendai Subway, and their ideas were adopted, with fuzzy systems used to control accelerating, braking, and stopping when the Namboku Line opened in 1987.

## Real-World Applications

Companies such as Boeing, General Motors, Allen-Bradley, Chrysler, Eaton, and Whirlpool have worked on fuzzy logic for use in low-power refrigerators, improved automotive transmissions, and energy-efficient electric motors. The Sendai Subway 1000 series was the world's first train type to use fuzzy logic to control its speed, and this system is 10% more energy efficient than human-controlled acceleration.

Interest in fuzzy systems was sparked by Seiji Yasunobu and Soji Miyamoto of Hitachi, who in 1985 provided simulations that demonstrated the feasibility of fuzzy control systems for the Sendai Subway, and their ideas were adopted, with fuzzy systems used to control accelerating, braking, and stopping when the Namboku Line opened in 1987.

## Real-World Applications

Companies such as Boeing, General Motors, Allen-Bradley, Chrysler, Eaton, and Whirlpool have worked on fuzzy logic for use in low-power refrigerators, improved automotive transmissions, and energy-efficient electric motors. The Sendai Subway 1000 series was the world's first train type to use fuzzy logic to control its speed, and this system is 10% more energy efficient than human-controlled acceleration.

Here are the search results for "Fuzzy control logic":

## Overview

A fuzzy control system is a control system based on fuzzy logic – a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values of either 1.

## Key Concepts

The process of converting a crisp input value to a fuzzy value is called "fuzzification". Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.

## Historical Development

Fuzzy logic was proposed by Lotfi A. Zadeh of the University of California at Berkeley in a 1965 paper. The first industrial application, a cement kiln built in Denmark, came on line in 1976. 

Interest in fuzzy systems was sparked by Seiji Yasunobu and Soji Miyamoto of Hitachi, who in 1985 provided simulations that demonstrated the feasibility of fuzzy control systems for the Sendai Subway, and their ideas were adopted, with fuzzy systems used to control accelerating, braking, and stopping when the Namboku Line opened in 1987.

## Real-World Applications

Companies such as Boeing, General Motors, Allen-Bradley, Chrysler, Eaton, and Whirlpool have worked on fuzzy logic for use in low-power refrigerators, improved automotive transmissions, and energy-efficient electric motors. The Sendai Subway 1000 series was the world's first train type to use fuzzy logic to control its speed, and this system is 10% more energy efficient than human-controlled acceleration.

Based on the search results, "consensus control" can refer to several different concepts depending on the context:

## Consensus Dynamics and Multi-Agent Systems

Consensus dynamics is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local information exchange.(no content)The consensus protocol, or agreement protocol, defines the rules of interaction that lead to convergence.(no content)Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

## Consensus in Distributed Computing

In computer science, a fundamental problem in distributed computing and multi-agent systems is to achieve overall system reliability in the presence of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation.

## Other Related Uses

The term "consensus" is also used in various other contexts, including consensus decision-making, which is a group decision-making process in which participants work together to develop proposals for actions that achieve a broad acceptance, as well as in distributed systems, control theory, and organizational settings.

Web search results for query: "Human-in-the-loop control system"

Links: [{"title":"Human-in-the-loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-in-the-loop"},{"title":"User-in-the-loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-in-the-loop"},{"title":"Hardware-in-the-loop simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardware-in-the-loop_simulation"},{"title":"Reciprocal human machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_human_machine_learning"},{"title":"Open-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-loop_controller"},{"title":"Motor control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_control"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Humans in the Loop (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humans_in_the_Loop_(film)"},{"title":"Out-of-the-loop performance problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Out-of-the-loop_performance_problem"},{"title":"Cybernetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybernetics"}]

## Human-in-the-Loop Control System

Human-in-the-loop (HITL) is used in multiple contexts and can be defined as a model requiring human interaction.(no content)HITL is associated with modeling and simulation (M&S) in the live, virtual, and constructive taxonomy.

### Key Characteristics

Although much can be done to automate systems, humans typically still need to take the information provided by a system to determine the next course of action based on their judgment and experience.(no content)In this type of simulation, a human is always part of the simulation and consequently influences the outcome in such a way that is difficult if not impossible to reproduce exactly.

### Applications

Human-in-the-loop systems have several important applications:

- **Simulation and Testing**: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) uses HITL simulation as an evaluation tool to allow air traffic controllers to test new automation procedures by directing the activities of simulated air traffic while monitoring the effect of the newly implemented procedures.

- **Machine Learning**: HITL is used in the context of machine learning, where humans aid the computer in making the correct decisions in building a model.(no content)HITL improves machine learning over random sampling by selecting the most critical data needed to refine the model.

- **Autonomous Systems**: In human-in-the-loop systems, a human must instigate the action of the weapon (in other words not fully autonomous).

I've completed a web search for "Cooperative control multi-agent." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents, and multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Cooperative Control Theory

Collaborative Control Theory (CCT) is a collection of principles and models for supporting the effective design of collaborative e-Work systems, and advances in information and communications technologies, artificial intelligence, multi-agent systems, and cyber physical systems have enabled cyber-supported collaboration in highly distributed organizations of people, robots, and autonomous systems.

## Key Aspects of Cooperation

Cooperation involves all aspects of coordination as well as a resource-sharing dimension to support goal achievement, and commonly exhibits a division of labor component among all participants.

## Multi-agent Planning

Multiagent planning is concerned with planning by (and for) multiple agents, and it can involve agents planning for a common goal, an agent coordinating the plans (plan merging) or planning of others, or agents refining their own plans while negotiating over tasks or resources.

## Applications

Multi-agent systems research includes applications in robotics, multi-robot systems (MRS), and robotic clusters, as well as possible applications in microrobotics where physical interaction between agents is exploited to perform complex tasks such as manipulation and assembly.

Multiagent planning is concerned with planning by (and for) multiple agents, and it can involve agents planning for a common goal, an agent coordinating the plans (plan merging) or planning of others, or agents refining their own plans while negotiating over tasks or resources.

## Applications

Multi-agent systems research includes applications in robotics, multi-robot systems (MRS), and robotic clusters, as well as possible applications in microrobotics where physical interaction between agents is exploited to perform complex tasks such as manipulation and assembly.

Links: [{"title":"Fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Software fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Control reconfiguration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_reconfiguration"},{"title":"Jakob Stoustrup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakob_Stoustrup"},{"title":"Fail-safe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fail-safe"},{"title":"Fault detection and isolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_detection_and_isolation"},{"title":"Configurable Fault Tolerant Processor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Configurable_Fault_Tolerant_Processor"},{"title":"System Fault Tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_Fault_Tolerance"},{"title":"Category:Fault-tolerant computer systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Fault-tolerant_computer_systems"},{"title":"Safety-critical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety-critical_system"}]

Here's an overview of fault tolerance control systems based on the search results:

## Overview

Control reconfiguration is an active approach in control theory to achieve fault-tolerant control for dynamic systems.(no content)It is used when severe faults, such as actuator or sensor outages, cause a break-up of the control loop, which must be restructured to prevent failure at the system level.

## Fault Detection and Diagnosis

Before control measures can be implemented, it must be at least determined whether a fault has occurred (fault detection) and if so, which components are affected (fault isolation).(no content)Fault detection, isolation, and recovery (FDIR) is a subfield of control engineering which concerns itself with monitoring a system, identifying when a fault has occurred, and pinpointing the type of fault and its location.

## Approaches to Fault Tolerance

There are two main strategies:

1. **Control Reconfiguration**: In contrast to control reconfiguration, accommodation is limited to internal controller changes. Control reconfiguration restructures the control loop itself.

2. **Fault Accommodation**: An alternative approach that makes adjustments within the controller without restructuring the entire control loop.

## Key Design Principles

The system had to be self-repairing and diagnosing – isolating a fault and then implementing a redundant backup while alerting a need for repair. This is known as N-model redundancy, where faults cause automatic fail-safes and a warning to the operator, and it is still the most common form of level one fault-tolerant design in use today.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification**: **Contribution**

This paper proposes several novel approaches and improvements:
- Improves conventional prescribed performance control (PPC)
- Introduces a hybrid human-in-the-loop approach for UAV decision-making
- Develops an adaptive fuzzy fault compensation mechanism for harsh environment operations

**Key Technologies and Methodologies Identified (8 triples)**:

1. **Control Theory** (concept) - Uses: Foundation for tracking control
2. **Unmanned Aerial Vehicle** (artifact) - Uses: Target application systems
3. **Consensus Dynamics** (method) - Uses: Enables cooperative flight coordination
4. **Fuzzy Control System** (method) - Proposes: Novel fault compensation mechanism
5. **Human-in-the-Loop** (concept) - Proposes: Hybrid human-UAV collaboration approach
6. **Fault Tolerance** (concept) - Uses: Addresses motor faults in harsh environments
7. **Multi-Agent System** (concept) - Uses: Framework for cooperative UAVs
8. **Tracking Error** (concept) - Uses: Key control requirement (sign-preserving constraint)

All validation checks passed successfully with proper Wikipedia URLs and comprehensive relevance descriptions for each entity.

Sources:
- [Control Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Unmanned Aerial Vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle)
- [Consensus Dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics)
- [Fuzzy Control System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_control_system)
- [Human-in-the-Loop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-in-the-loop)
- [Fault Tolerance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_tolerance)
- [Multi-Agent System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Tracking Error](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tracking_error)
